issues.title: Freeze version tag until breaking changes are needed
issues.author: cjpatton
issues.body:
At this point it would be helpful if we stopped bumping the version tag when a purely editorial draft is cut. This allows deployed clients and servers to be forward compatible.

Of course, if breaking changes are needed at some point, then it's appropriate to change the tag as well.

Note that draft-ietf-ntp-roughtime-11 has version `0x8000000b`.

comments.author: dansarie
comments.body: I just made a pull request (#4) that should address this.

issues.title: Grease support
issues.body:
[From a mail from](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/ntp/qa0iCrhqeVEtwt28pGH32dSV0sY/) @davidv1992:

> First of all, regarding the ver tag, there is no requirement for
servers to ignore unknown versions in that tag. this means that
technically it is valid behavior right now for a server receiving
unknown versions to reject that packet, even if there is version
overlap. This seems highly undesirable

> Second, the grease section seems to contain no mechanisms for actually
exercising either the ignoring of unknown tags by servers (or clients
for that matter) nor for exercising the version negotiation mechanism.
Given the experience in TLS with this, this is probably a really good
idea to include.

> Finally, the grease section indicates the server must send malformed
packets some amount of the time to clients to exercise the rejection
mechanism, but doesn't specify in which way it may malform the
packets. Thus servers could do this in ways that could potentially
reduce future design space. I would be much more comfortable if we
specified a specific set of things the server is allowed to do to
create malformed packets, so that we at least have control over which
parts of the future design space are excluded.

This was also discussed at [interim](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/minutes-interim-2024-ntp-04-202409171500/) yesterday.

issues.title: Undefined variables in Sec. 7
issues.author: dsibold
issues.body:
Section 7 introduces the time interval (t-delta-sigma, t-delta+sigma), in which neither delta nor sigma is defined. From the specification of the interval I would assume that delta is a systematic error whereas sigma is a statistical error. 

Delta and sigma should be explained in order to help the reader to understand the paragraph.

issues.title: Regression between draft-07 and draft-08
issues.author: dansarie
issues.body: In draft-07, we changed the DELE signature context from `RoughTime v1 delegation signature--` to `RoughTime v1 delegation signature`. It then changed back in the following draft. Was this intentional or is it a regression?

comments.author: wbl
comments.body: Sounds like a regression. I plan to go through this week and address a bunch of these issues, forwarding ones that need more input to the list

issues.title: Signed response needs to include a hash over entire request and server's maximum supported version
issues.author: dansarie
issues.body: To detect downgrade attacks, the signed response must include a hash of the entire request and the server's maximum supported version. The Merkle tree should be populated with hashes over the requests instead of nonces.

comments.author: dansarie
comments.body: The VER tag should also be included in the signed response.

issues.title: Max tree height needs to be specified
issues.author: dansarie
issues.body: The maximum tree height should be specified. Currently, there is an implicit height due to the maximum packet size, but this should be made explicit.

issues.title: Multiple version numbers in requests
issues.author: dansarie
issues.body: Currently, sending multiple version numbers in requests is allowed. This complicates server implementations and it is unlikely that clients will send more than one version.

issues.title: Sec. 3.2 (editorial)
issues.author: dsibold
issues.body:
Sec 3.2, second paragraf, first sentense
Remark: The timestamps t_1, t_2, and t_3 are not used anymore else in the document. I would therefore suggest removing them. This is a suggestion for how the sentence may be rephrased.

A Roughtime server ensures that the timestamp included in the response to a query is generated after the reception of the query and prior to the transmission of the associated response.

issues.title: Sec. 5.4 (editorial)
issues.author: dsibold
issues.body:
Sec. 5.4, third paragraph
Remark: In my view, it should be described more precisely what "consistent" means in this sentence.

Sec. 5.4 last paragraph, second sentense. 
Remark: I suppose the promise of the server does not only includes that it started to compute the signature but also that it finished this computation. I would suggest rephrasing the sentence to make this more clear.  Here's a suggestion:

Validity of a response does not prove that the timestamp's value in the response is correct, but merely that the server guarantees that it signed the timestamp and computed its signature during the time interval (MIDP-RADI, MIDP+RADI).

issues.title: Sec. 8.2 (editorial)
issues.author: dsibold
issues.body:
Sec 8.2, fifth sentence.
Remarks: I’m not sure which delay the sentence is referencing. And also I would suggest not keeping the „system-provided parameter" secret.

Sec 8.2, sixth sentence.
Remarks: I'd suggest not only to write "... not consistent" but to be more specific about what that means.

issues.title: Wrong format for malfeasence reporting
issues.author: dansarie
issues.body:
The format for malfeasence reporting specifying in both draft-11 and the current version on Github can not be used to verify a chain of responses. Three values are required for each response:  "nonce", "publicKey", and "response". The random blind used to generate the nonce from the previous response also has to be specified.

The description of how clients can chain requests should probably also be improved.

issues.title: Does delegation work?
issues.author: wbl
issues.body: In the current draft DELE identifies a range in which the actual signing key can be trusted. However, determining that this interval has expired poses a chicken-egg problem.
